file_content.text: We obey.
As you wish.
Whatever you need, we're here to provide. Within extensive limits, granted.
If there's nothing else, perhaps we'll work on our memoirs.
Agent--we're finalizing our exit report for the Diplomatic Service. Thirty-four pages of seating charts, ambassador profiles and appendices.
We'll transmit it to our superiors, and then we're yours full time.
You're going to be an asset to this team, Vector.
Glad to hear it.
We certainly hope so.
Any second thoughts about leaving diplomacy for Intelligence?
Will you miss the service?
We'll miss it, and we're sorry to hand over the unfinished work--but they'll do fine without me.
You know, we used to advise first contact missions to new star systems; we met some unusual people.
But we haven't had many new experiences since Joining the Killiks. Time to broaden our horizons.
To see everything fresh, from a Killik perspective?
That ought to be interesting.
Something of the sort. Tastes, sounds, smells--they're all a bit different.
But we won't bore you. Lead the way.
After what happened, are you still part of the Killik hive mind?
How are things with the nest?
The nest has no concept of betrayal, and no concept of forgiveness. If they considered us a threat, they'd have eaten us.
So we remain the Dawn Herald. And one day, we will make amends.
You said before the Killiks approved of your departure...
How are things with the nest?
Yes. We will return someday, with more to offer the nest than ever. In the meantime, we'll follow your lead.
You're a covert assault operative. There won't be time to "broaden your horizons."
Don't plan on sightseeing.
Of course. We'll be following your lead.
From now on, you'll be writing fewer reports and taking orders seriously. Lives depend on your obedience.
I expect discipline here.
We understand, and we gladly follow your lead.
We look forward to this. We used to advise first contact missions into the Unknown Regions; it gave us a taste for novelty.
We're a different person now but we're sure you'll show us interesting things.
Yes, Vector?
Agent. We'll never be a great spy or "covert assault operative." But you've helped us be a diplomat and a Dawn Herald.
We're grateful for your patience and your guidance.
You don't have to be grateful. We're here to support each other.
You're my husband.
Nonetheless.
You've been family to us, and we're thankful for your guidance.
You've been a brother to us, and we're thankful for your guidance.
There aren't many people I trust to save my life. I'm glad to have you at my side.
We've made a good team.
Any reason you mention this now?
What brought this on?
Trust me, all the credit and the blame is yours.
Any guidance was accidental.
Fair enough.
We received a message from the Killiks--the Colony embraces the Imperial alliance, and offered us the chance to become Dawn Herald to all nests.
We refused, as our priorities are clear. We'll work with you and defend your legacy until the end.
What can I do for you, Vector?
We've been speaking to friends in the Diplomatic Service--putting Doctor Lokin's lessons in persuasion to good use.
It took some brokering to find a gift for you--an ulikuo gemstone once owned by the Tapani noble houses.
Are you just feeling generous, or is there an occasion?
What's the gift for?
Ah, you finally figured out how to win me over.
[Flirt] I knew I liked you.
And just in time, apparently.
Traditionally, the Tapani nobles present the stone as part of a marriage proposal. Which is what this is.
That's sweet, Vector, but I don't really know what to do with it.
Jewelry isn't really my thing.
Neither do we, although it's apparently presented as part of a traditional marriage proposal. Which is what this is.
We know you can never Join us. You can never share our thoughts. But if you can't live in our world, we can live in yours, forever.
I love you, Vector. I'll gladly share my life with you.
Yes, let's get married.
What if I could come to your world? I could become a Joiner, too.
What if I'm willing to Join?
It would mean giving up everything you are, everything you wish to become. We have no desire to see you do that.
We love you. Will you marry us?
I will marry you, Vector. I love you, too.
Absolutely.
Then we have an agreement.
Yes, alright. But don't expect me to wear a ring in front of the boys.
Just don't get possessive.
We'll negotiate terms.
We don't have a ceremony planned, and for the sake of your cover, perhaps it can't be officially sanctioned.
But it is real. We are one.
It's a long time since the cave. It hasn't always been good... but you've always been worth it.
I'm glad I found you.
As have you, agent. You always will be.
Show off for me. Tell me something only a Joiner could say.
Say something Killik-y.
There are patterns in your electric aura that are yours alone. They taste like frost and spices.
We will remember them always.
So many years as a diplomat, and you still don't know when to quit pushing.
Don't you ever shut up?
And now you'll have to put up with it for all the years to come.
I just can't.
I'm sorry, I wasn't expecting this. Marriage... it's not in the cards for us.
Marriage wouldn't work out.
It's alright. We understand.
For as long as you wish, we'll stand by you. And if the day comes when it ends, we'll return to the nest better for our time together.
Vector. What's going on?
It's strange... since the summit, our mind keeps drifting back to diplomacy, but we have nowhere to apply our skills.
Still, we should be grateful Killik-Imperial relations are going well. And it's time we rededicated ourselves to your work.
You planning to learn sniper techniques?
How do you mean?
Nothing so extreme, but we can discipline ourselves and study our opponents.
Making allies is vital to what we do. I need you as a diplomat more than I need a soldier.
Diplomacy is part of my work.
We don't intend to stop being a diplomat.
Summits are all well and good, but we're in the middle of a war. Focus on the team.
I can use more firepower.
Back to basics. We agree.
We've been privileged, over these past months. Until opportunity comes again, on to the less glamorous job we signed up for.
Agent. The summit is over.
It was not without incident. Daizanna, of the Iesei nest, is dead.
I thought things were looking up. How did the summit turn violent?
What happened?
I'm sorry to hear it. I know you felt a... connection to Daizanna.
You two were close...
Yes, we did.
No great loss. I assume her memories are still with the nest.
Can't really mourn a Joiner.
Yes, but there is loss nonetheless.
Falner Oeth--our contact in the Diplomatic Service--attempted to sabotage the proceedings.
Daizanna was caught in an explosion saving an ambassador, and when we traced it to Falner, he had a... speech prepared.
Damn you! Listen to them--do you want to ally the Empire with these creatures?
Everything they do defies what we stand for--the Killiks are an abomination.
Our Empire is based on the notion that a great individual rises to the top, and the lesser masses follow.
The Killik hive mind devours greatness, absorbs every possibility into a mire of primal instinct.
We found his words troubling, and his actions more so.
He's one man, and a crazy man at that. Trying to bomb the summit proves it.
Don't take him too seriously.
He's wrong, you know. The Colony shares the Empire's ideals--it only expresses them differently.
I expect that didn't help the talks?
How'd the summit go afterward?
No, but we reconvened after Falner was gone.
Whatever he may have done, Falner Oeth isn't entirely wrong.
The man has a point.
He's wrong enough. The Colony shares the Empire's ideals--it only expresses them differently.
The Colony allows billions of Killiks and Joiners to serve something greater--the nest consciousness. Just as Imperials serve the Sith and the Emperor.
That is what we told the others. That is how we signed a treaty between the Empire and the Killiks.
It's been a long time coming, but you made it happen.
Congratulations, Vector.
You did wonderful, Vector. You should be proud.
Congratulations, Vector.
We are. And we're proud of you.
I wish it hadn't gone the way it did.
I'm sorry for what happened.
We couldn't have known Falner would go so far.
In a few years, you may regret not listening to Falner.
Hope this wasn't a mistake.
Possible, but we don't think it likely.
Both sides will open their borders to trade. Protocols will be set for military and diplomatic contact.
You and Daizanna... even Falner, you all brought us to this point. Our future is hopeful.
Things are looking bright. Let's enjoy it while it lasts.
Agreed.
You've got time on your hands. Why don't you work me into that future somehow?
[Flirt] Our future is, too.
We'll see what we can do.
Next thing you know, there'll be Killiks selling membrosia in Kaas City.
Bugs and Imperials together...
Let us dream, agent.
The galaxy has a way of crushing hope. Let's aim for survival.
Don't get too optimistic.
One way or another, then.
We end a verse in the Song of the Universe. Soon, we will hear another.
We're set, agent. Preparations for the Killik-Imperial summit are underway, and the first ambassadors are arriving on-site.
We're meeting on Alderaan, in the house of Thul. We couldn't think of a more appropriate place.
Alderaan it is. Where's my invitation?
I assume we're going.
You don't want to sit through it all--but there is a favor we'd like to ask.
Who'll be attending? What's the agenda?
What do you have planned?
Daizanna, of the Tatooine nest, will be there along with delegations from eleven more hives. Falner Oeth will be among our people from the Diplomatic Service.
You could've picked somewhere not in the middle of a war.
Alderaan isn't exactly safe.
Sadly, we're not sure that's true anymore--though it does relate to a favor we'd like to ask.
More than any other Imperial, you've seen the nests and how they function. Your word could carry weight.
Before we leave, we'd appreciate your honest assessment--one final report that we can present to the Imperial summit attendees.
An alliance with the Killiks would benefit the Empire immensely, and I'm not afraid to say so.
I'll gladly support a treaty.
I'll have a report to you by the time you reach Alderaan.
We look forward to it.
I'm sorry, Vector, but you'll have to win this one on your own.
I'm staying out of this.
Very well. We enjoy a challenge, and we'll see you when we return.
I'll write up my findings--but you may not like what I have to say.
My report: Killiks are crazy.
The Killiks are dangerous, and we've been lucky so far... but that may not last.
We appreciate your candor. We'll see you when we return.
You said you wanted to talk?
Yes, but we'd like some privacy. No crew members, no Killiks, no emergencies... if you could arrange it.
Give me ten minutes and we'll have an empty ship.
Of course.
I can arrange it. Should I dim the lights? Pour a drink?
[Flirt] This could be fun.
If you like. We'll meet back shortly.
I can send the others out for supplies, but the comm stays on. Business first.
I can't promise anything.
Always. We'll meet back shortly.
Vector?
I'm here, agent. Surprise.
You sound good when you talk this way.
I like hearing "I" from you.
How can you be... normal?
What's happening to you?
You have nice eyes. It's good to see them.
You look wonderful.
You look different without your electric aura--but just as lovely.
The Aebea nest taught me to repress the pheromonic bond; I can hold it for a little while.
Tell me what this is about, or I put blaster bolt in your knee.
Stay back. Don't move.
We're--I'm sorry, I should've told you in advance. I'm repressing the pheromonic bond.
This is a time for us to be together; one you needn't share with Oroboro or the Colony.
You're a smart man. I don't like sharing.
Good choice.
I'll remember that.
The others will be back soon, but I'm glad we could have this. I do love you, agent.
I love you, too, Vector.
Likewise.
Then it all works out.
I take it you can't stay this way?
Back to being a Joiner?
No. It takes a toll, and we--I--couldn't survive doing it often. I hope it's enough.
Forget love. Just keep me entertained.
Don't go soft on me.
I'll make a note of it.
Now we return to work.
You're sweet, but the man I care for isn't human.
Adorable, but this isn't you.
We didn't know, but we expected to learn one day--we're glad it happened like this.
And we're glad to be with you.
Trust me with who you are. Because I'm glad to be with you, too.
Don't hide yourself, please.
We will remember.
Why don't we take advantage of our privacy? You are still mostly human?
[Flirt] We're still alone...
In all the relevant ways, the Joining doesn't change us.
That's enough excitement for now. I'll let the crew come back aboard.
Let's call it a day, Vector.
As you wish, agent.
If you think this is romantic, you've severely misjudged.
I'm really creeped out now.
Agent, stop.
We don't usually worry about making people uncomfortable with our appearance--but we care for you.
If you were part of the nest, you would know our thoughts. Since you aren't, we sought to prove our feelings a human way.
You don't have to prove anything to me. I love you.
I love you.
We love you, too.
I'm not here because you do things "a human way."
Stupid bug-man. [Kiss him]
We will remember.
The others will return soon, and another crisis will demand our attention.
Crises define our lives. No sense complaining about it.
Things are what they are.
None at all. We're at your service.
I'm not done with you. I'll make sure we get another private moment, and soon.
We'll find other times.
We'll count on you for that.
When the crew comes back, if you could not mention anything...
Don't tell anyone about this.
Of course, agent. Whatever you wish.
Look, Vector--we shouldn't have come this far. I'm sorry.
This isn't working out.
As are we. But we will endure.
Agent. We've been speaking to the nests in preparation for the Killik-Imperial summit.
They're so much in tune with their biology--the Kolosolok are warriors as large as houses, and they're convinced the Empire should be crushed.
But the Saras are weavers and shapers, and they're eager to trade.
I'd think you were used to Killik quirks by now.
You sound almost surprised.
From our nest on Alderaan, yes, but the Colony is so much greater.
You're all one species, aren't you? How can that much biological diversity be possible?
How can Killiks vary so much?
From the beginning, there was the Joining, and that links us even as our bodies evolve over millennia.
Of course, that's just what our memories tell us--the Colony has never specialized in scientific research.
So long as you don't start a war; we don't need bantha-sized Killiks marching on Dromund Kaas.
Just keep them in line.
We are mindful of that concern, having seen the Kolosolok dreams.
We should return to our preparations; we'll talk later.
We have news, agent.
We've been conferring lately with the ambassadors, Moffs, speakers for the Sith--all with their own agendas and concerns, none with any love for the Killiks.
But we swayed a few, and found ways around others. Now the Diplomatic Service has agreed to seek a treaty.
An alliance with the Killik Colony. It's what you've been wanting.
This sounds like good news.
What we've been working toward together.
You convinced these people all on your own?
How'd you manage all that?
We've been a diplomat longer than we've been Dawn Herald.
Are these people out of their minds--or are they playing you?
I don't believe it.
They see the Colony as an opportunity, and they want the credit for exploiting it.
Some of the nests are still reluctant--Horoh and Manam in particular--but all parties involved have agreed to a summit.
We'll preside over the negotiations ourselves.
I'm at your disposal. I want this to work.
You'll have my full support.
So do we. Thank you, agent.
Any idea what sort of treaty we could end up with?
What terms are on offer?
We expect a military alliance is off the table, but a non-aggression pact is possible, as are agreements on trade and territory.
Imagine--Colony and Imperial representatives in one room. It shall be interesting.
There's a lot that could go wrong, with Killiks and Imperials in the same room.
That's a dangerous setup.
Security will take time to arrange, as will the seating. But we can make this work, agent--if we do it right.
It is done, agent.
We can scent the pulse of your heart; we can taste particles of solar radiation bead like dew on our lips.
We have undergone the Chrysalis of Tranquility, and we are reborn.
You've never mentioned this "Chrysalis of Tranquility."
Care to explain that?
I don't know what that means, but I'm glad you're excited.
If you're happy, I'm happy.
Whenever you go into full Killik mode, I start to get worried.
You're freaking me out.
There's no need for that.
The chrysalis is a ritual of the Dawn Herald. It makes us stronger, better able to face the enemies of the nest, and enhances our link to the universe.
It requires the stillness of spirit we now have. We'll fight alongside you.
My brave, strange protector. You know I'm glad I have you.
Nowhere I'd rather be.
We do.
You know something that I don't?
Expecting trouble?
Our enemies seem to be multiplying, and there's no end in sight to this war. We should be prepared.
Can you mind-control Geonosians now? Spit acid? Anything?
Show me something useful.
Not that we're aware, but perhaps we'll experiment.
You've brought us this far, and we will fight alongside you.
What's going on?
Agent. In our work with the Diplomatic Service, we find ourselves talking to people we once knew.
We've been contemplating this:
Hello, Vector. It's Anora--I don't know if you remember me, but Bryson said he thought you would, and...
I wanted to talk to you. I know things didn't end well, but I never forgot.
You need to get out of there. Come back to Dromund Kaas, and we'll get you help. We can undo what the Killiks did.
There are still people who care about you.
We've watched it seventeen times and meditated to the static.
It can be difficult to be reminded of your past.
That must be hard to see.
Can it?
You two used to be a couple?
Who is she?
Are you sure you want to discuss your ex-girlfriend with me?
This really isn't my business.
I'm sure this is none of my business.
This seems a little personal.
Apologies; but we would like an outside perspective.
We were nearly engaged to Anora, very long ago. We never considered that there are people who want us... restored to what we were.
But watching this, feeling nothing--we know we're no longer who we were when we loved her.
People change, even without becoming part Killik; it's part of life.
Nothing wrong with that.
We think you're right--but we had to hear it from another. And we are content.
If you could be restored, would you want it?
Do you want to be un-Joined?
No.
If your relations with the Diplomatic Service are causing problems, I can cut you off.
I don't want you distracted.
That's not necessary.
We had to know if our reaction was unnatural, but we don't think it is. We are... content.
What do you have for me?
Encouraging news. Watch:
Dawn Herald. Forgive the message, but our emissaries were out of reach and we couldn't wait to link with you.
Imperial scout ships entered Colony space and made contact yesterday. We traded in membrosia, silk and star maps.
We could smell the men's fright, but they left in peace. Perhaps you were right after all.
A long way from a signed treaty, but it's a start.
It looks like your work is paying off.
Sounds like it's going well.
So far.
Is there something going on between you and that Joiner?
[Flirt] She seemed friendly...
Daizanna is a nest-mate, and we value her. But she isn't you.
Glad you have your priorities straight.
Smart man.
We trust you to remind us.
You were saying something about a treaty?
So, back to the discussion.
She isn't your superior officer, either. Just so we're clear.
Keep remembering that.
Very clear.
In any case, things progress, and even the Diplomatic Service is listening to us again.
You and that Joiner seem to get along.
She seemed very friendly...
Daizanna is a nest-mate, and we find her insight illuminating.
So long as Killiks aren't feeding Imperials to their young...
At least no one was eaten.
No, human flesh isn't optimal for growing larva.
We're in touch with the Diplomatic Service, as well. There's still resistance, but we're progressing.
Killiks and Imperials may share space in our lifetime.
Agent. There's something we want you to know.
Our obsession lately has been with the Colony and the Diplomatic Service.
We're sure you've noticed that we've been distant.
You've had a lot on your mind, and I've had an Empire to save. Not a lot of time for bonding.
Life's been keeping us busy.
And at least we're using our time productively. Regardless...
We were getting close for a while. Then you pulled back.
Yes, I've noticed.
Yes. It wasn't intended.
I'll take your word for it, but I haven't been that bothered.
Not particularly.
Somehow, we aren't terribly surprised. Regardless...
We're finished repairing ourselves. We found the part of our mind that understood humanity and we're relearning how to use it.
We couldn't have done this without you. And we don't want to be distant anymore.
No more disappearing when things get difficult?
Then stay with me.
What we did was necessary, but we won't go through it again.
Maybe you should make sure I'm convinced. I do have other options.
[Flirt] Is that so?
As you like.
Vector, we had a chance, but maybe this isn't the way to go.
Look, let's not do this.
We see. Would you mind telling us why?
There's too much difference between us. Not just species, but--I'm sorry.
It just wouldn't work out.
I like that you're so trusting. It makes you easy to play with.
[Flirt] Sorry, I can't resist.
Before our Joining, we don't remember people being this difficult.
What will be the next verse of our song?
We'll discover it together.
I'd like to know, too.
As you wish.
Have you really forgotten what comes next?
[Flirt] I'll give you a hint.
We haven't relearned everything.
But we'll work on it.
I'm not sure I can get used to kissing a Joiner.
That's still just... weird.
What can we say? At least we're memorable.
We're glad to have you, agent.
Yes, I would mind. Let's just call it over.
I don't have to explain.
You are a friend and our superior. We'll abide by your wishes.
But you have helped reawaken us, and for that, we're grateful.
Agent--we received a small gift from the Diplomatic Service, in appreciation of our work with the Killiks.
A package of wine, meat and breadfruit, all imported from colony worlds. Not inexpensive, and a bit extravagant during wartime.
The Diplomatic Service must be happy with you. Maybe you'll get your Killik treaty after all.
That's a good sign.
Aren't extravagant gifts part of the diplomatic process?
You don't approve?
Maybe, but we'd rather they treated us as one of their own--not a foreigner to be won over.
Check the package for listening devices. I don't need the Diplomatic Service spying on us.
Make sure to sweep for bugs.
Already done, but we'll double-check.
In the meantime, you're welcome to help yourself--we may as well enjoy the taste of progress.
You're back. Did you find your man?
We spoke to the Republic governor. If you'll join us, we'll report the details to Falner Oeth.
My friends. It's been too long.
Falner. We assume you've heard from Thenoth?
He contacted me from an Imperial transport. Apparently we promised to work with him--not what I requested, but the service can make do.
There was no need to make him a Joiner, when he was amenable to discussion.
Your reputation in the Diplomatic Service is secure. Now, about our request...
Everything's in place, then.
You haven't lost your touch as a diplomat after all.
Nice work, Vector.
Not entirely, no.
Now you have what you wanted. But we can destroy your reputation just as easily.
We made you, we can break you.
I am well aware of your capabilities.
You kept your promise--Thenoth's assistance resulted in my promotion. I will keep my promise to you.
Some important people are waiting, Vector. They're very interested in a potential Killik alliance.
You arranged this?
As soon as I knew we could work together. Check the data I'm streaming to your main console.
Thank you, Falner. Excuse us a moment, agent.
It's like talking to a bug wearing a man's skin. I don't know how you stand it.
I don't understand. You helped him.
He bothers you? Then why...?
We're practical people, and we take the tools we're given. But!
He's a brave man and a loyal Imperial.
Vector is my friend.
You can't be serious.
Vector creeps everyone out; still, you get used to it, and the Killiks are quite a resource.
He's repellant, but valuable.
Those creatures are anathema to everything the Empire stands for. There's no place for great men in a hive mind--only animal instinct.
I'll be relieved when you people finish this scheme and get rid of the Colony for good.
Agent. They listened. They don't understand yet, but they listened.
The Diplomatic Service has requested my aid, and wants to initiate relations with the Colony.
Congratulations, Vector. You might get your alliance after all.
That's excellent news.
We're a long way from that. But we can hope.
We thank you, agent--as a friend, and as Dawn Herald. We've begun something good.
Listen, Falner Oeth is keeping his deal, but he's repulsed by Killiks. We can't trust him.
I just talked to Falner...
He admits it? We always did get an odd sense from him.
It's out of his hands now, though. We should watch him--but we'll be focused on the future.
We're taking an awful risk. If this doesn't work out, and the Killiks become an enemy...
Let's hope this is smart.
They won't. We'll see to it; we swear.
You wanted something, Vector?
We do not neglect our duties. We are Dawn Herald; we do this for the nest.
Agent--we've had another request from Falner Oeth, our ally inside the Diplomatic Service. We need to take a short leave.
We can spare you for a little while. What does Falner want this time?
Shouldn't be a problem.
I heard you talking to the emissaries of the nest. Is everything alright?
You were speaking to Killiks.
Everything's fine--the distance from our kin is unusual, and causes rifts.
Are you taking orders from the Diplomatic Service, now?
Falner Oeth isn't your boss.
Of course not, but we'd like to maintain an amiable relationship.
Falner's stock is rising, but he needs further acclaim before he can push for a Killik-Imperial alliance.
He's asked us to visit a former Republic governor named Yoganerr Thenoth and win his cooperation... by turning him into a Joiner.
So you're supposed to strip a man of his individuality and make him part of the nest.
You mean brainwash him.
Give me the details on Thenoth. Who is this man, and what makes him important?
Tell me about this governor.
Formerly of Ord Mantell, possessed of quite a few secrets the Diplomatic Service could make use of.
He joins the nest, you learn everything he knows and share it with the Empire. You can't blame Falner for asking.
It's a clever plan.
We'd hoped Falner wanted us for our diplomatic skills, not... for this.
The Joining should be a gift. But we will find a way.
Whatever you decide, I'll back you. Good luck.
Do what you have to do.
Thank you.
You know this isn't right. Don't do it, Vector.
I don't want you Joining him.
We appreciate your concern. We ask that you trust our decision.
I don't care how you handle it. Finish this up and get back to the ship as soon as possible.
Just make it fast.
As you wish.
Agent. You recall we spoke to the Diplomatic Service about building an alliance between Empire and Killiks?
Falner Oeth--the man who offered his backing in return for our assistance--has asked us for his first favor.
What's our diplomat friend after?
Tell me what he said.
You don't owe him anything, you know.
You can still back out.
No, but his support could make a difference.
You can't tell me you don't have doubts about him.
I really don't trust that man.
Of course we do. But we don't have another option.
Falner wants our notes on various families and unaligned worlds in the Questal Sector. He means to bring that sector into the Empire.
We worked in Questal a long while, and we knew its people well. It's... odd to see someone else take the reins.
I don't see any reason not to help him with negotiations.
Sounds harmless enough.
Nor do we. We'll proceed to contact him; Falner will get the credit, and the Empire will get a new sector.
Not the traditional role of a Dawn Herald--but if this works, the Colony will benefit.
You don't talk about your old life.
You miss being a diplomat?
We don't often have a reason to think about it.
We do miss negotiating--reaching out to understand people, synthesizing their needs.
Daizanna of the Iesei nest says that desire makes us a better Joiner. It's only small comfort.
You haven't forgotten your training. Even as Dawn Herald, you're an ambassador.
You still have your skills.
Perhaps--but seeing men like Falner again, we think it's best if he handles negotiations.
Apologies, agent. This is something we need to think on more deeply... but we are glad you stand by us.
I remember her. I didn't know you two were in contact.
Daizanna was the other Joiner?
Through the unseen emissaries that travel with us. We hear her voice from time to time.
But that isn't relevant now. We'll give Falner what he wants, for the sake of the Empire and the Colony.
Dwelling on the past doesn't help. You're a Dawn Herald and an espionage operative.
Try not to think about it.
Not a diplomat. True enough--we'll put the negotiations in Falner's hands.
No one else is taking the reins. Tell Falner we aren't playing his game.
We're not working with Falner.
Very well, agent. As you command.
Agent. We heard back from the Diplomatic Service about our proposed alliance with the Killik Colony.
Our report was soundly ignored. It seems we have less credibility than we thought.
You don't sound very concerned.
You're taking this well.
You worked for them for years, and this is what you get?
Why won't they listen to you?
We're twice compromised--no longer human and no longer a diplomat.
You can't even talk without sounding like a Killik. What did you expect?
Somehow, I'm not surprised.
We expected our friends to risk their careers--and we understand why they can't. But there is still hope.
A colleague named Falner Oeth sent the update on our report along with a message.
He wants us to call him, accompanied by our "handler." We believe he means you.
Put him through. We'll see what he wants.
Then let's talk to him.
You worked with him in the Diplomatic Service?
Who is this guy?
Not directly. Oeth spent his time with ex-Republic worlds, while our specialty was first contact.
We met several times, at conferences and the like, but we wouldn't say we knew him. This should prove interesting.
Whoever this man is, he's trying to pull something.
That can't be a good sign.
Quite possibly, but we'd like to know what. Shall we?
Master Hyllus, I'm so glad you got my message. How are you? How's Anya?
Anora. We haven't seen her in some time, but we hear she's well. And your son?
Stationed on Balmorra, still hoping to join the Shadow Fist.
And you must be the handler. It's a privilege to meet you.
I want you to know I wouldn't try anything without your approval, but I'm hoping you'll loan out Vector to me.
And you must be Cipher Nine. It's my privilege to meet you.
Rest assured I went through channels to arrange this--Imperial Intelligence has agreed to loan me Vector so long as you're amenable.
Vector contacted you about a Killik alliance. Why would you need him?
What do you mean by that?
Tell me your proposal, and I'll see what we can do.
I'm happy to negotiate.
I'm not in the business of loaning my people to diplomats.
Don't waste my time.
Of course not, and I know this is an exceptional request.
My superiors don't see the wisdom in Vector's advice. I do, yet I lack the authority to force the issue.
Someone is blocking you?
Terrab, Sabini--the usual crew. If I'm to win them over, I need influence.
Vector--with your ties from the service and the Colony's knowledge, I could amass a string of victories.
And the more I succeed through your consultations, the better chance your Killik-Imperial alliance comes to pass.
We'll help your career, and you work for us.
It's a deal, Falner.
As you say. I'll be in touch with specifics.
What's your take on all this?
Vector? It's your call.
He wants us to play politics. But that is how things are accomplished.
Perceptive man. I'll be in touch with specifics.
We appreciate your aid--and your patience, agent.
We're doing this to serve our people. We don't meant to neglect your company.
Don't worry about it, Vector. We've both got enough on our minds.
You're doing what you need to.
Sure enough. Maybe some day that will change.
Tell you what--next chance we have to slip away, we'll find a planet all to ourselves.
[Flirt] We'll find time, soon.
We'll hold you to that.
Tell someone who cares about emotional garbage.
I don't want to hear it.
As you wish. We'll keep you apprised about Falner.
We appreciate your help, agent. We'll make it worthwhile--to you, to the Empire and to the Colony.
You expect us to pull strings and build up your career, and in return, we get a favor?
You're a slimeball.
If you want to be mercenary about it, yes--but we both benefit.
Falner's right. This is part of playing politics, in or out of the Empire.
We'll follow your lead--but next time he comes to us, we think we should take his offer.
How are things, Vector?
Agent. When we communed with the other nests, we saw a force for change in the galaxy.
There are Killiks as large as starships and as small as mites; Joiners from a hundred species on a thousand worlds.
We mean to report on the Killik Colony to the Diplomatic Service.
The Killiks are a force to be reckoned with, and the Empire should know.
Not a bad idea.
The Colony's been in hiding for a long time; the Killiks may not appreciate it.
Will the Killiks approve?
We've shared thoughts with Daizanna of the Iesei nest, and we've assessed the limits of their cooperation.
Not even a smile for me? You are focused today.
[Flirt] All business, I see.
We are--still, it's you who inspires us.
You transferred out of the Diplomatic Service. It's not your responsibility.
You don't report to them.
We still serve the Empire, and our former superiors are in the best position to help.
If the service can make entreaties to the Colony--if we make them an ally--we'll have a foothold in the Unknown Regions.
We'd have access to Killik craftsmanship, Joiner information--even without their military support, they'd be invaluable.
What would an Imperial-Killik alliance take?
Do you have a plan?
We've outlined an proposal. The Killiks want peace and resources, and the Empire can offer both.
I agree. But why bother with the Diplomatic Service when we could pull the strings ourselves?
You need spies, not diplomats.
An alliance built on manipulations can't last. We've done so before, and seen the consequences.
This needs to happen with the backing of those in power. And it needs to happen before someone else finds the Colony.
Are you sure you're not letting your personal situation color your view?
You're not exactly unbiased.
Certainly, we'd like to show the beauty of the Colony to others--but we haven't forgotten politics.
And if the Empire doesn't make allies of the Killiks, someone else may get to them first.
However I can assist, say the word.
You have my full support.
We'd ask you to sign off on the report. Other than that, we'll keep your offer in mind. Thank you.
Convincing the service--let alone the Sith--to support this won't be easy.
It'll be a tough sell.
We're well aware of that, agent. But there was a time when this was our life.
We believe in it, and we'll find a way.
The bugs are unpredictable. Keep your focus on our mission, and leave foreign policy to someone else.
Killiks are too dangerous.
As you wish, agent. But we still have friends in the Diplomatic Service, and we'll be keeping abreast of the situation.
Agent. We've had time to think since reuniting the Killik Colony--not that our work hasn't kept us busy, but...
We didn't actually thank you for allowing our pilgrimage. You should come with us next time.
No need to thank me. You ever need support, just say the word.
We work well together.
We'll try not to make you regret that offer.
Take a blanket and some rations, go sightseeing under the stars? You just want me alone.
[Flirt] Could be fun.
We could use a change from Killik company. You're a novelty.
We'll pack some rations and go sightseeing on strange planets. Just say when.
What could be more fun?
We're glad to have friends with a sense of adventure.
I've got enough Killiks in my life without searching for more.
You've got to be joking.
All you've been through, and you're still bothered by insects? You surprise us.
There's something else: In the old days, as a diplomat, we used to be able to read people.
Since our Joining, that's gotten harder, so we have to be direct: is our relationship becoming unprofessional?
Unprofessional? Vector, you don't always need to treat me like your superior.
Don't worry about ranks.
Then how do you want us to treat you?
I get to decide what's professional; one advantage to being friendly with your superior officer.
[Flirt] I wouldn't worry.
Clearly. So tell us, agent--just how friendly are we?
Come by my quarters some night and you can find out.
[Flirt] Maybe I'll show you.
If you don't know the answer, I'd rather not have this conversation.
Figure it out yourself.
You are perplexing, agent. But we'll abide by your wishes.
I'm not sure what you're getting at.
You'll need to explain.
We don't mean to be coy--we take our job seriously.
But we also value our relationship--we think of you as a friend.
I care for you. That's all I can really say.
You mean a lot to me.
That's all we need.
We still have much to relearn, in this life--feelings the Killiks can't perceive.
We're in no hurry. Just know that we're here.
You're disappointing me, Vector.
[Flirt] Just a friend?
Friendship isn't what I want on your mind.
That does make things clear.
We'd like to continue this... but we've kept you from your duty long enough. The Song of the Universe will not pause.
Don't get the wrong idea, Vector. I'm not interested in you.
Friends, maybe--but no more.
Of course, agent. We're glad you confirmed it.
In any case, we should get back to work--we promised Kaliyo we'd keep the hatchlings away from her quarters, which means some training is in order.
The last thing we need is infighting among the crew--or bugs under our pillows.
Good idea.
Spoken like the warrior-poets of old.
Kaliyo hasn't said much about you. Everything going alright?
How're you two getting along?
After some early missteps, we're learning to tolerate one another--we no longer invite her to dejarik games, she no longer spits in our tea.
Give us a few months; we've negotiated with worse.
Don't let that woman scare you. She's not in charge of this ship.
Feel free to ignore Kaliyo.
If we can avoid a shooting war with minimal effort, we figure it's worthwhile. But mostly, we just give her space.
Let us know if anything comes up; we're ready to move when you are.
So, you made it back from your pilgrimage.
Our journey is over. We saw strange worlds, and markers set in stone and frozen lakes of steaming colors--but no Killiks.
The Colony found planets that suited them, but none that could support them.
They divided into a thousand nests, each going its own way, to a hundred different stars.
The Killiks left Alderaan and dispersed. Maybe some of the nests survived, but...
That's the last of it, then.
...but they remain lost to us. It's alright, agent--we're grateful for what we've learned.
I know this isn't the end you were hoping for.
I'm sorry, Vector.
We forged a connection to the lost colony. Even if we didn't find it, this means a great deal.
I think I've humored you long enough. Ready for business?
Now can you get back to work?
We are. Thank you for doing this, agent.
In any event--we're sorry, what?
There is a scent here!
You're not giving up already?
But we welcome you nonetheless. We are Daizanna, of the Iesei nest.
Daizanna. I represent the Sith Empire, along with Vector Hyllus.
Introductions are in order...
Yes. But are you, Vector...?
Daizanna of Iesei. We are Dawn Herald of Oroboro.
Maybe you should handle this.
Vector? Your call.
You'd better have a good reason for slicing my ship's comm systems.
I want an explanation!
It's alright.
Daizanna of Iesei, we are Vector Hyllus, Dawn Herald of Oroboro.
Oroboro. We barely recognized the scent.
The Colony still exists, spun across the stars--our nests, still kin. A trillion and more Killiks will dance and sing tonight!
Your ship followed Vector on his way back from the pilgrimage?
How'd you track down Vector?
You're getting a little familiar with Vector for my comfort.
Hands off the man, please.
She seems to like you, Vector.
Guess you made a new friend.
She's a Joiner, agent--it's how we are.
Why does stirring up a galactic hive seem like a bad idea?
Killik unity sounds dangerous.
We understand your concern, but agent--Killiks are meant to be as one. This is right.
Yes.
The Iesei shall rejoice. She offers dancing and membrosia; the chance to walk the tunnels of the Synapse-Comb.
The Dawn Herald must come with us. As his partner, you may accompany and share in our joy.
I'd love to see a Killik celebration. Lead the way.
I'll gladly join you both.
Don't worry; we'll be out before the pheromones bond to your system.
The membrosia runs in golden rivers!
You're doing well. Accompany the Joiners, if you wish; morning comes soon.
We're impressed--you held up well. More to the point, you brought together the fragments of an ancient people.
We can't fully express our gratitude. We hear the singing of a thousand nests, and are at peace.
I think I'd just get in your way. But enjoy yourself.
Go ahead on your own, Vector.
We're disappointed, but we respect your wishes.
We'll see you shortly, then.
Come. We begin.
I'm not turning Vector over to some alien hive.
You're not taking anyone.
We thank you and your nest for the offer, Daizanna.
As you wish. We will celebrate this reunion nonetheless.
Oroboro will know.
You've brought together an ancient people. It is a great gift.
We hear the singing of a thousand nests, and we are at peace.
I'm glad you're in high spirits. Call it a day, then?
Hope you enjoyed the vacation.
Agreed, agent.
I know this means a great deal. But you're as much human as Killik.
Just don't forget who you are.
We know. Today was a day for the Dawn Herald. Tomorrow... may be different.
Thank you, agent. For all your help.
I didn't do it for you, or for the Killiks. I did it to gain an edge.
The Killiks may be useful.
The Colony owes us a favor. One day, I'll call it in.
Imperial diplomacy at its finest, agent.
We've been dreaming lately.
Great spitcrete vessels weep dew above the Castle Lands; their engines scorch the air. Dartship swarms shade the sky, humming a song of farewell.
We remember the Great Migration, when the lost nests departed Alderaan.
You said no one knew what happened after the other Killiks left.
You mentioned this before.
We still don't. But our travels have caused a buried memory to surface.
What was the point of the migration? Why did so many Killiks leave?
Why did your nest stay?
That, we don't remember--resources, perhaps. But there's something else:
You were never there, Vector. You were born and raised in the Empire.
You sound very Killik today.
Nonetheless, we remember.
In our dream, there is a mosaic that mirrors the stars and shows us the lost ones' destination.
We request leave for a pilgrimage, agent--to follow the first steps of the migrant Killiks.
You think the lost nests are still out there?
What do you expect to find?
I don't see any harm in that.
Since you ask nicely, sure.
Vector, if you want a favor, you'll have to do better than that.
[Flirt] Ask me nicely.
We'd ask you to come with us, but all we expect to find is dust and petrified shells.
You want to abandon our mission so you can follow your insect ancestors?
There's no time for vacation.
Call on me, and I will return.
It's been millennia since the migration, and we doubt we'll see more than dust or petrified shells.
Still, the journey honors our kin. We're already packed.
I'll be here when you're done. Take care of yourself.
Good luck, Vector.
And you.
We've spent a lot of time and money on you; you'll need a bodyguard to keep you out of trouble.
Someone has to protect you.
We are Dawn Herald; we have some ability to defend ourselves.
You're not here to serve as your people's emissary. You work for me.
Just remember your loyalties.
Yes, we do. But consider how it might help you to please the Killiks.
You wanted to talk?
Yes. The suns are warmer here.
Nothing that smells so green when the gamma bursts come.
Vector? Are you alright?
Are you okay?
[Remain silent]
Even the song can rest.
I'm speaking to you Vector. Don't ignore me.
Snap out of it.
We must go. Auras mingle.
Apologies, agent. Emissaries from our nest--they stowed away aboard the ship, and have accompanied us since we left Alderaan. They're becoming quite sociable.
There was something you wanted to discuss?
You asked to speak...
I don't see a swarm around you. Can they turn invisible?
Where are they?
No, but they can grow very large, or very small. These live within our flesh.
If you must socialize with your pets, do it in the crew quarters.
Don't let it be a distraction.
Your objection is noted. Nonetheless, they represent the nest.
The Killiks of Alderaan know little of the galaxy--only what they absorb through Joiners. Our journey teaches them a great deal.
But there is something that intrigues us--intrigues the nest. The fate of our lost kin.
I've found Colicoids, Geonosians, other insectoids--but no Killiks off Alderaan.
You're the only ones I've met.
We're not surprised.
What "lost kin"?
"Lost kin"?
I'm sure they're crawling around somewhere.
Check under a rock.
It isn't quite that simple.
Alderaan has only a handful of nests, sleeping beneath the Castle Lands and awakening every few centuries. The other Killiks migrated offworld millennia ago.
No one knows what became of them, or whether they survived. But the migration is a... primal memory. We miss them.
If the Citadel has any record of Killik encounters, we can find out.
I can check with the Empire.
We appreciate that, agent. It may help.
How can you miss long-lost ancestors?
But you've never met them.
The nest never forgets; memories sink into the unconscious, then resurface ages later.
So long as the Killiks are contained, they're no real danger. If there are whole colonies out there...
They could be a threat.
Even we confess that nests can be dangerous.
We don't know if it's truly important to find them. But as Dawn Herald, we'll be watching.
Agent. We hope you don't mind, but we were wondering something.
Do you have a family? Siblings, a husband, people to go home to after a mission?
"A husband?" Are you asking if I'm single?
[Flirt] You're not subtle.
That was part of the question. We'd like to hear the answer.
No, there isn't anyone. Clear enough?
I'm not married, Vector.
Perfectly clear. We don't mean to pry.
I think you should explain.
I recall some man waiting for me at home, but I don't let him get in my way.
[Flirt] Let me think on that.
Get in the way of what, exactly?
Life is hard out here--you take what comfort you can.
You know the answer.
We imagine you do. Thank you, agent; we enjoy these talks.
I wouldn't be a very good operative if I didn't use all my skills. And I can't worry about jealousy...
Seduction's part of the job.
You have a utilitarian view of the world, agent. We'd like to hear more sometime.
I can get you a textbook, if you'd like.
You've been a Killik too long.
We'll try to puzzle it out on our own. Thank you agent--we won't keep you further.
Do you have a family? Siblings, a wife, people to go home to after a mission?
Not much room for that in our line of work.
Spies don't have families.
We suppose not.
Not a question I was expecting, I'll confess.
Why do you ask?
We aren't trying to pry.
Leave my personal life out of your interests. Am I clear?
That's none of your business.
Perfectly clear.
We're just trying to understand how you--how anyone--in this job keeps a tether to the real world. None of us can exist in isolation forever.
Eventually, violence and deceit become second nature. This becomes your real world.
You learn to adjust to it.
Maybe it shouldn't, agent. And maybe you should find another way before it does.
Then again, we're new here. Apologies.
You can live apart from the civilian world. You just don't do it alone.
[Flirt] We help each other.
We see. It's odd, living outside the nest--there's an intimacy among the Kind that can't be replaced.
Still... to bridge that gap between persons... We'll remember your advice.
Ordinary life is easy to forget. That's why we have to remind one another.
Agents support each other.
Fair enough. Then we all share that responsibility.
Thank you, agent.
You're the last one who should be worried. There's no place in the "real world" for a half-Killik.
You're not even human anymore.
So we've been told before. Frankly, agent, we're not convinced.
Last night, we ate our first ration bar since leaving the nest.
We savored the flavor for two hours. We could taste every nutrient, every chemical compound and trace of foil.
Do you know what Joining the Killiks does to a person's senses?
Should I be sending you on more nighttime missions?
Enhanced senses? Useful.
We can't see into every spectrum, or smell poison under our nose--but our eyesight has improved.
That does bring up something we want to discuss. How do you see our role as operative on your team?
No--but shouldn't you have noticed months ago?
You seem surprised.
All we ate in the nest was membrosia. This is something new. Thank you.
You get excited over a ration bar. That's cute, Vector.
[Flirt] You're almost sweet.
We'll let you know when we try the Chaka noodles.
But--we did have something more serious to discuss. How do you see our role as an operative on your team?
I don't know, and I don't care to. Now did you want something?
Spare me the details.
Apologies--there is business.
In the Diplomatic Service, our responsibilities were defined by Imperial policy; in the nest, duty was determined by caste.
How do you see our role as an operative on your team?
I'm not sure what you're getting at.
Why do you ask?
You're a capable partner, and I value your input.
I consider you a major asset.
And our skill set?
Keeper described us as a covert assault agent. Our role as Dawn Herald gives us that capacity.
We just don't know if that's the only reason we're here, or if it should be.
You have abilities I don't, as does your nest. We should use them.
You're also here as a Killik.
We see. We'll give that due consideration.
Thank you for your help, agent.
If there's information you have, or aid you can provide--tell me. I'm still learning your talents.
Help me identify your skills.
So are we, in a sense. But agent... our whole life, we've been a diplomat.
Whatever else we become, perhaps we shouldn't abandon that so readily.
You are a covert assault agent, and you will use all your abilities to that end. Understand?
You kill the Empire's enemies.
You take my orders and you eliminate your targets. Understand?
You do what I tell you.
We do. Thank you for your honesty, agent; we do value it.
What can I do for you, Vector?
Agent. Excuse us a moment.
We hear the Song. The nest awakens.
Light fills the hive, and we are one.
Apologies. It's the hour of revitalization and as Dawn Herald, we still participate--in spirit, if not in person.
Do what you need to; I'm not here to interfere.
No need for apologies.
We appreciate that, and we'd like you to understand.
You talk about being Dawn Herald, but I don't know what that is.
What does all that mean?
I don't need you meditating in the middle of a fight.
Keep your mind on business.
It's a custom, not a law of Joiner biology. That's what we wanted to discuss.
Traditionally, the Dawn Herald is a warrior and emissary for the nest--one who confronts the unknown.
As herald we are more than a typical Joiner, and we retain a sense of individuality. It's also why we're useful to you.
You're physically enhanced and linked to the nest.
It makes you a better soldier.
Yes. Ironic that we fight more now than we ever did in the hive--except in the Season of Akamaka.
You aren't entirely part of the hive mind--but you don't want to leave it, do you?
Tell me about being a Joiner.
The Joining changed us, and we are content.
In any case, we still honor the Killiks' gift--but surely everyone carries over rituals and habits from their lives before Intelligence?
Who I was then made me who I am today. For the most part.
I carry my past with me.
You should tell us about your past, when we have time. We'd like to hear it.
Your old habits are still unusual, as these things go.
You're making a joke...
Fair enough. You can't blame us for trying, agent.
Having a history makes a person vulnerable. Habits should be forgotten; connections must be severed.
An agent needs a clean slate.
As you say, agent. We'll keep it in mind.
Useful or not, it makes you more Killik than Imperial. And I don't like Killiks.
You're a creepy bug-man.
Of course, agent. We'll respect your attitudes.
We should talk in private, when you have the chance.
We'd like to talk at some point.
Something we can do for you?
We apologize for surprising you, but it took time for us to become aware of your presence. More to find you.
We aren't interested in you or your ship.
We thought we'd lost the nests of Alderaan, until you followed. Our flit-ship pursued you here.
Even after he was gone, he left an impression we could follow.
Our emissaries are not far from your own; let them touch, and bring knowledge.
Acknowledged. We'll await your commands.
We'll do our best to live up to expectations.
How can we help?
We regret to say we can't help you.
We appreciate your professionalism.
We live to serve.
The electrons are singing.
Of course.
Understood. We'll follow your lead.
What is it, agent?
Understood.
Agent?
That's not necessary.
